Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was Mr. Singh's failure to disclose his daughter a material misrepresentation under Section 40 of IRPA?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Singh did not disclose his daughter at immigration, claiming ignorance of paternity. DNA tests later confirmed he was the father.
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Mr. Singh is inadmissible due to misrepresentation.
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Immigration Appeal Division's decision
Crimes.Court_Ruling: The court upheld the misrepresentation claim but found the humanitarian and compassionate analysis required reconsideration.

Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review followed by remand for reconsideration
Crimes.Review_Standard: Reasonableness of the Immigration Appeal Division’s decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Singh's claim of ignorance of paternity was not accepted
Crimes.Application_Basis: Omission of a biological dependent constitutes material fact
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Set aside exclusion order and reassess humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Section 40(1)(a) IRPA – Misrepresentation leading to inadmissibility
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of disclosure despite knowledge or constructive knowledge of possible paternity
